Y SÅµn - The Soul of a Nation

12/04/2023

Evie Rees reviews this Welsh film about the foundation of S4C, a Welsh language television channel

Image by IMDb

By Lawrence Mason

Y SÅµn tells the story of a hard-earned victory for Welsh language and culture by detailing the struggle surrounding the foundation of the Welsh language channel, S4C.

Beginning in 1979, when Margaret Thatcherâ€™s new Conservative government broke its manifesto promise to establish a television channel solely in the Welsh language, the film rides the waves of anger and national tensions that followed. Director Lee Haven Jones and writer Roger Williams have crafted an exciting blend of historical and contemporary media, creating a colourful celebration of a key moment in Welsh history and identity. Fittingly, the film is part funded by S4C and showcases the Welsh talent and spirit fostered by S4Câ€™s 40 years of existence.

Although focused on the journey to S4Câ€™s success, Y SÅµn emphasises that this is not simply a story about a television channel. Instead, at stake is the â€œsoul of a nationâ€. By exploring a turning point in modern Welsh history, Y SÅµn becomes a reminder of the importance of having a readily available platform for Welsh in the popular media landscape. The film is an electrifying insight into how suppressing the language and culture of a people leads to growing nationalism and civil disobedience.

However, apart from the enormity of its overarching themes, Y SÅµn succeeds in portraying the lives of the individuals involved in the battle for Welsh broadcasting. Perhaps the most prevalent of these is Rhodri Evanâ€™s accomplished portrayal of Gwynfor Evans. As a figure grappling with feelings of failure after political losses, the film successfully conveys his steadfast commitment to Wales, the Welsh language, and its people. His internal struggles, conflicts, and inspirations are cleverly conveyed to the audience. The peak of his devotion is highlighted in Y SÅµn by Evansâ€™ decision to undertake a fast until death, designed to put pressure on the English government and secure the future of Welsh media and language. Similarly, the commitment of the Welsh youth to the national cause is represented in Ceri Samuel, played by Lily Beau. Her eventual decision to risk her job and reputation and Gwynforâ€™s preparation to lose his life for Wales emphasises the personal sacrifices undertaken to allow the Welsh language and Welsh media to achieve its position today.

The energy Roger Williams and Lee Haven Jones have injected into this portrayal of Welsh history is immediately apparent. Throughout the film there are interesting interjections of archival protest footage, an apt reminder of the long-standing political tensions that existed (and still exist) between England and Wales. Additionally, the film makes clever use of colour and captions. Scenes featuring English politicians are shot in black and white whereas those in Wales are in strong colour. This deftly imbues Wales with a sense of progression and new life and makes London seem remote and austere. Similarly, a lively soundtrack of Welsh music by artists such as Catatonia ensures that Y SÅµn is a spirited depiction of Welsh resistance. Although the use of graphics was perhaps not always necessary in already significant scenes, overall they are extremely successful in making the film feel fresh and energetic, imbuing it with the feeling of a heist movie or crime genre.

The very existence of Y SÅµn as a Welsh media film reflects the struggles it depicts. To have a film in Welsh (with accompanying English subtitles) that focuses on Welsh victories and struggles is evidence of the success of the fight for Welsh media. The final scene of Y SÅµn invites viewers to contemplate this and reminds us that without the dedication of people such as Gwynfor Evans and the potential of young people like Ceri Samuel, the existence of films such as this would not be certain. Y SÅµn thus becomes a homage to those that defended the rights of Welsh artists to create and display their work on a national platform. It also highlights the exciting future of the Welsh language in the current media landscape of streaming services, social media and digital content.

Overall, Y SÅµn is an inspiring insight into the successful foundation of Welsh media. As a proud depiction of Welsh culture and talent, the film is an exciting portrayal of the unvanquished spirit of a nation.
Y SÅµn will be available on i-player from the 9th of April, 2023.
